<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 322, 390, 336]]<|/det|>
# READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 352, 828, 367]]<|/det|>
If you have been given an Answer Booklet, follow the instructions on the front cover of the Booklet.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 368, 722, 383]]<|/det|>
Write your Centre number, candidate number and name on all the work you hand in.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 384, 327, 399]]<|/det|>
Write in dark blue or black pen.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 400, 495, 415]]<|/det|>
You may use a soft pencil for any diagrams or graphs.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 416, 601, 431]]<|/det|>
Do not use staples, paper clips, highlighters, glue or correction fluid.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 448, 285, 462]]<|/det|>
Answer all the questions.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 463, 907, 493]]<|/det|>
Give non-exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place in the case of angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 494, 590, 508]]<|/det|>
The use of an electronic calculator is expected, where appropriate.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 510, 606, 524]]<|/det|>
You are reminded of the need for clear presentation in your answers.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 540, 606, 555]]<|/det|>
At the end of the examination, fasten all your work securely together.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 556, 756, 571]]<|/det|>
The number of marks is given in brackets [ ] at the end of each question or part question.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 572, 440, 587]]<|/det|>
The total number of marks for this paper is 50.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 588, 907, 618]]<|/det|>
Questions carrying smaller numbers of marks are printed earlier in the paper, and questions carrying larger numbers of marks later in the paper.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[272, 865, 729, 880]]<|/det|>
This document consists of 3 printed pages and 1 blank page.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 73, 96, 91]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 920, 122]]<|/det|> A biased die was thrown 20 times and the number of 5s was noted. This experiment was repeated many times and the average number of 5s was found to be 4.8. Find the probability that in the next 20 throws the number of 5s will be less than three. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 104, 920, 123]]<|/det|> [4] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 152, 96, 170]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 151, 920, 185]]<|/det|> In Scotland, in November, on average \(80\%\) of days are cloudy. Assume that the weather on any one day is independent of the weather on other days. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 198, 148, 216]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 198, 920, 231]]<|/det|> Use a normal approximation to find the probability of there being fewer than 25 cloudy days in Scotland in November (30 days). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 214, 920, 233]]<|/det|> [4] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 244, 151, 262]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 243, 680, 262]]<|/det|> Give a reason why the use of a normal approximation is justified. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 245, 920, 263]]<|/det|> [1] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 291, 96, 310]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 291, 732, 310]]<|/det|> A sample of 36 data values, \(x\), gave \(\Sigma (x - 45) = -148\) and \(\Sigma (x - 45)^2 = 3089\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[126, 322, 148, 341]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 322, 594, 341]]<|/det|> Find the mean and standard deviation of the 36 values. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 323, 920, 341]]<|/det|> [3] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 352, 153, 371]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 352, 920, 388]]<|/det|> One extra data value of 29 was added to the sample. Find the standard deviation of all 37 values. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 368, 920, 386]]<|/det|> [4] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 414, 94, 432]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 414, 148, 432]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 414, 920, 448]]<|/det|> Find the number of different ways that the 9 letters of the word HAPPINESS can be arranged in a line. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 432, 920, 450]]<|/det|> [1] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 462, 153, 480]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 462, 920, 495]]<|/det|> The 9 letters of the word HAPPINESS are arranged in random order in a line. Find the probability that the 3 vowels (A, E, I) are not all next to each other. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 477, 920, 495]]<|/det|> [4] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 507, 151, 525]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 507, 920, 540]]<|/det|> Find the number of different selections of 4 letters from the 9 letters of the word HAPPINESS which contain no Ps and either one or two Ss. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 523, 920, 542]]<|/det|> [3] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 570, 96, 588]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 570, 920, 603]]<|/det|> A hotel has 90 rooms. Estimate the value of \(n\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 749, 920, 766]]<|/det|> [2] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 796, 94, 814]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 795, 920, 828]]<|/det|> The lengths, in centimetres, of drinking straws produced in a factory have a normal distribution with mean \(\mu\) and variance 0.64. It is given that \(10\%\) of the straws are shorter than \(20 \text{cm}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[126, 842, 146, 860]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 842, 319, 860]]<|/det|> Find the value of \(\mu\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 842, 920, 860]]<|/det|> [3] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 873, 153, 890]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 873, 920, 905]]<|/det|> Find the probability that, of 4 straws chosen at random, fewer than 2 will have a length between \(21.5 \text{cm}\) and \(22.5 \text{cm}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 889, 920, 907]]<|/det|> [6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 74, 92, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 920, 139]]<|/det|>
Judy and Steve play a game using five cards numbered 3, 4, 5, 8, 9. Judy chooses a card at random, looks at the number on it and replaces the card. Then Steve chooses a card at random, looks at the number on it and replaces the card. If their two numbers are equal the score is 0. Otherwise, the smaller number is subtracted from the larger number to give the score.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[126, 151, 153, 168]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 151, 569, 170]]<|/det|>
Show that the probability that the score is 6 is 0.08.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 152, 920, 170]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 183, 151, 201]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 183, 584, 201]]<|/det|>
Draw up a probability distribution table for the score.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 183, 920, 201]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 214, 146, 231]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 214, 364, 231]]<|/det|>
Calculate the mean score.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 214, 920, 231]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 244, 920, 278]]<|/det|>
If the score is 0 they play again. If the score is 4 or more Judy wins. Otherwise Steve wins. They continue playing until one of the players wins.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 292, 148, 310]]<|/det|>
<label>(iv)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 292, 698, 310]]<|/det|>
Find the probability that Judy wins with the second choice of cards.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 292, 920, 310]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 323, 153, 341]]<|/det|>
<label>(v)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 323, 811, 341]]<|/det|>
Find an expression for the probability that Judy wins with the \(n\)th choice of cards.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 323, 920, 341]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]
